title: 5.0 out of 5 stars One of the Best Compact Portable Speakers
author: Student Nurse
content: I picked this up at the Apple Store the other day when trading in my old MacBook for the college promo (Gift card of $150 with purchase). With my gift card, I decided to inquire about the new Beats Pill that they have in store. One of the reasons I went for this item is because it was essentially free for me ($150 speaker + $150 Gift Card = Gift to me). Below is my review:Sound Quality: In the formative years of the Beats Pill, it has been a very popular speaker to consumers who are shopping for a unit that is under the $300 price tag. Just like the Beats headphones, this speaker is very well known to the general public & even further to the audiophiles (Like Myself). My first thoughts of the sound quality were ‚ÄúHow is this going to sound?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWill this live up to its price?‚Äù & ‚ÄúHow good is the build quality?‚Äù. Needless to say, when I got it up & running, WOW WAS I IMPRESSED!!!!!!This generation of Beats Pill blows every one off its predecessors in the water. The woofer alone is unbelievably powerful with the incorporation of newer & more durable materials. It reproduces great lows along with outstanding mids & highs. As for the tweeter, I believe this was also upgraded. The clarity from the tweeter is exceptional & performs well even at higher volumes.Build: The new build quality is MUCH more advanced than previous models. To start, the speaker is now on a(n) angle to promote better sound distribution throughout your space. The materials used to bring this speaker together feel very durable & solid. In addition to the new build, the speaker offers a plethora of other great features including a(n) IP67 rating, better battery life & a whole new look.Other Comment(s): The only comment I have about this speaker (Which I am sure is correctable by a software update in the near future) is with the on/off function(s). This was a little tricky for me at first, but I eventually figured it out. In order to turn the speaker on/off, you have to hold the power button for 1-3 seconds (I usually do it for 2 seconds & it works). This may be a turn off for some consumers as a lot of people today don‚Äôt want to go through the trouble of having to learn how to turn it on/off the right way.Overall: I would say that all in all, this is a great speaker for under $200 if you are in the market for great sound quality, portability & power. I bought the ‚ÄúStatement Red‚Äù as the ostentatious or loud red color got my attention & I loved it (I personally like speakers with crazy colors / designs). If you are in the market for one, either buy it here or check it out in person. Needless to say, you won‚Äôt be disappointed with this speaker.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 4, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Bass Heavy
author: Geomancer
content: As you can probably tell from the product description heavily focusing on the subwoofer, you won't be surprised to learn that this speaker is very bass heavy. That's fine for songs that complement that kind of sound, but is a determent to anything else. For example listening to an audio book it doesn't sound very good and I actually prefer my phone's built in speaker or a regular set of headphones. There is no EQ feature, even if you download the Beats app. Speaking of the Beats app, it doesn't really have any use. It will tell you battery life, and remind you what the controls are, but that's it. The "one touch connect" feature did not work, I had to manually connect in my Bluetooth settings (Android, Samsung Galaxy S20 FE).For controls there are four buttons. A power button, multi-function button (play/pause/next/previous), volume down, and volume up. They are the same color as the speaker, do not light up, and are difficult to see. I initially had some trouble turning it off because you have to hold the power button. However if you don't hold it long enough it just gives you a battery life indicator, hold it too long it goes into pairing mode. You have a 2-3 second window between those two functions to actually get it to turn off.Volume wise, it does get pretty loud. Loud enough to hurt if you're nearby. Bass of course travels well and far, be aware that you will annoy your neighbors if your outside with the volume up. Perhaps even at a mid volume because it is so bass heavy. Not great for apartments because of that, at least if you don't want to be that annoying neighbor.If you have two of these, you can sync them together either to just make them even louder (why would anyone want that? It already hurts at max volume), or as a stereo pair.For the price, I would have preferred a speaker with a more balanced audio profile. For tracks that do emphasize bass though it does sound pretty good. Overall I would classify my annoyances other than the sound profile as minor.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 28, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not bad for the price
author: M.J. Shearer
content: I own a plethora of bluetooth speakers, one even costing 10x this one. But, for a small portable form factor, this pill doesn't sound half bad. It is definitely not my favorite in the sound quality department, but the portability factor makes it a keeper. Right now, I'm testing it on my kitchen window sill and it provides me with adequate sound whilst I rustle up grub for the fam. Highs are clear, mids are punchy, bass is present but it won't knock your socks off. If you're looking for a balance between portability and sound quality, then this might be your ticket at 150$. BUT, if you want better sound quality, save up another 100 bux and you can find a larger (even much larger) speakers that will SA-MOKE this one, but, you WILL sacrifice portability. One issue I found with this speaker is that the rubberized texture on the back is a dust and animal hair magnet. (Two cats and two GSD's...you GSD owners out there know the struggle) It will not wipe clean with your hand, but a very damp paper towel works like a charm.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 10, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beats pill returned with an amazing and sleek speaker for IOS/ android
author: Alan
content: This is a very small and compact speaker, but for its size, it packs a serious punch. It's comparable to the JBL Flip 6. Sure, that speaker has even better bass, but this more complete package for its price, with speakerphone and in my opinion, more sexy design.-The bass is great, and the overall mid and high range is excellent, but I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs the best among portable speakers. This is overall a very bass-heavy speaker. I only own the black one, but I‚Äôm interested in trying out other models when I get a gold one (because it‚Äôs sexy af).-This is definitely the best-looking and sleekest portable speaker. It‚Äôs minimal, smooth, and easy to carry around. Sure, for the price, you can argue that you can get a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù speaker, but what this speaker offers is a well-rounded package: nice sound with great bass, goes well with home decor without sticking out, and minimal with a beautiful design. It's especially easy to access if you're an Apple user. Speakerphone has decent clarity and nice usages in times.-Even though it says 24 hours of battery life, take it with a grain of salt. The fact is, the higher the volume you play, the more battery it consumes because it uses more power in the drivers and woofers to push out bass and sounds. So, don‚Äôt complain too much if you see faster drainage than advertised, lol. I play around 60%-70% volume range and very bass heavy songs. so I get about 6 1/2 hours from what I observed. Yours might vary.-The biggest critique I have is that it‚Äôs the worst-sounding speaker if you go above 80% volume. The distortion and fuzzy sound are awful. The higher the volume, the less bass you‚Äôll hear, and the highs and mids kick in instead. To be fair, most small speakers are like this anyways. The best volume range I found is 30%-70%, especially 60%, which produces the most balanced bass and highs.In conclusion, if you want a small yet sleek speaker with great sound, then this is for you.By the way, don‚Äôt even compare this to the JBL Charge 5. It literally has different usage, and the size difference is there, lmao. A bigger and more expensive speaker can push out more sound and bass, LMAO. So yeah, it‚Äôs kind of like comparing apples to pears, lmao. I only say this because so many people compare this to the Charge 5 or other bigger speakers.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Pill punches far above it's weight class!!
author: Brian Severn
content: Beats Pill (2024) is a high quality product, from the Apple'esque packaging, to the incredible sound output from this small [tiny?] Bluetooth speaker. Incredibly easy to use, connect via Bluetooth and your off to the races.This speaker is about the diameter of a Coke can, albeit longer. It has a pre-attached teather that seems strong enough. Claims to be IP67 water resistant. It comes with a small instruction manual and a USB-C charging cable (USB-C YAY!!!). They claim the battery life is 24 hrs, and it may well be as we've been evaluating it for about a week off and on every day and it's still going strong.I tested it via Bluetooth, mainly streaming via Apple Music, and or it's size it packs quite a punch! Decent mids and highs, and it has bass! Not tons of bass [expected for it's size, it's just physics), but it's decent, if not exceptional given the size of this, but that is expected of any Beats branded speaker product, and this one doesn't disappoint! Another neat feature is that it allows the pairing to two Pill units for stereo music. It's easy to control, there are four buttons: power button, multi-function button (play/pause/next/previous), volume down, and volume up.I really like It also has a built-in mic so you can use it as a speaker phone as well, and it works pretty good.In summary, for the price, compared to other "party" speakers around the same price class, the Pill punches far above it's weight class, feature sound clarity with decent bass, lots of volume, and simplicity in design as we've come to expect from Beats. While maybe not the cheapest "party" speaker out there, it is among one of the best, if not the best, in it's price class.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 13, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Statement RedStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing Sound and Versatility
author: Jennifer
content: It‚Äôs not just a speaker, but also a portable wireless charger and a great companion for any music lover on the go. The sound from this small speaker is impressive. The bass is rich, and the mids and highs are clear, delivering a full, immersive audio experience. With up to 24 hours of battery life, this speaker lasts through even the longest days. The speaker connects seamlessly with both Apple and Android devices. Pairing is quick and easy, and the connection remains stable without any drops. There is a built-in microphone that is a handy feature for taking calls or using voice commands. The call quality is clear, and the microphone picks up my voice well, even in noisy environments. The Campagne Gold color is sleek, modern, and looks great in any setting.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Compact and powerful speaker...

content: This Beats Pill speaker is a fantastic portable speaker. It‚Äôs compact and easy to take anywhere. I mostly use this out by the pool, so I like the IP67 water rating. It‚Äôs been heavily splashed several times, with no ill effects. The battery life is excellent, and easily lasts me through a couple of days of listening. It comes with a USB-C TO USB-C charging cable.I love that this doubles as a speakerphone. I can connect it to my laptop for work calls, and the sound quality is excellent. Beats is a quintessentially Apple product, but don‚Äôt let that scare you off if you‚Äôre an Android fan like myself. This was simple to connect in my Bluetooth settings with both my Samsung S23 Ultra phone and my Samsung S9 Ultra tablet.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beats is BACK!
author: Justin
content: Look, don't tell Dr. Dre this but I really wanted a new Beats Pill as my dedicated shower speaker. Just something I can set on the shelf by the shower and jam out to without worrying about it getting wet. I misplaced my old one years ago and I always liked the pill shaped form factor.Fast forward to 2024, and we have a brand new Beats Pill that is redesigned from the old model. You still get the pill shape, but now there's some nice updates like the lossless type C listening, improved bass drivers and larger battery capacity...about of days worth of Beats now!The packaging and design are definitely exquisite...it is an Apple product, and it shows in the design and style. There's support for both Apple and Android too which is nice.Sound quality is superb as expected too. Sharp highs and nice thick, booming bass. It definitely leans to a heavier bass sound, which is fine as the end result is still really balanced and crisp.The verdict? A triumphant return for the Beats Pill üî•
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 28, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars HUGE audio punch in a small package - just what you expect from Beats!
author: Brett
content: Beats has long been popular for producing audio products - headphones, earbuds, speakers and so on - with great sound that are loud and pack a punch in the form of "boosted" bass notes. In that case, this new Pill wireless speaker is more of the same great recipe. In a fairly compact form factor you get a Bluetooth speaker (it can connect with any Bluetooth device though the documentation is focused rightfully on what most people will do - either Apple or Android phones) that gets VERY loud with VERY rich/boosted bass. The audio is also clear for things like spoken word, so that's a positive overall.Outside of that, the Pill is water resistant (not waterproof, so don't drop it in the pool or leave it out in a thunderstorm, but it's okay - probably - if it gets splashed a bit or drizzled on somewhat - meaning that it's great for outdoor parties given the volume) and has solid battery life. I do like that it can act as a portable battery bank, charging phones if you need to. It's not the primary function, but it's nice to see manufactures add value-added extra functionality that doesn't require any extra accessories or things to carry along. The Pill appears to be very well-built and should prove quite durable. As an added bonus, all the packaging is recyclable - kudos to Beats on that!So if you like your music loud and bass heavy, then this is the wireless speaker for you. If that's the case, give it a try today!

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Sounds good. Not overly loud. Needs more buttons
author: Carpe_Diem
content: This Bluetooth speaker is on the higher end of the price range for a small form factor speaker.Priced similarly to the JBL Extreme 2 (which I also have) the sound quality is about the same. Which is to say, very good for a small speaker.Compared to the JBL, the Beats Pill is:Not as loudHas a slightly better sound quality.Slightly smallerDoes not have a carrying strap (which you can also use to hang the speaker)Pairs automatically with Apple devices and can be tracked using Find MyBoth offer multiple speaker pairing.My biggest complaint about the Pill is that there are just not enough buttons. There is no dedicated power button, and in fact there are no instructions anyplace in the Apple/Beats ecosystem that tell you how to turn it off. (Push the Action button for more than 1, but less than 1.8 seconds.... how dumb is that?) With only 4 buttons, there are too many button sequence combos to remember. Seriously, a volume up/down AND a track up/down would have made life so much easier.All in all, this is a nice sounding Bluetooth speaker, with some good features, let down with a dumb user interface. If you don't mind learning a few tricks to use this device it will be great.However, if you are one of those people who doesn't read instructions, get something that is more intuitive to use.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect Mid-range Bluetooth Speaker
author: REDBLINKER
content: This speaker is my 3rd JBL. I first bought the JBL Pulse 5 speaker awhile back, and I really love that one, especially for the light show it can do, but it's a little large to pack up and haul. Then I bought the JBL Flip 6 which is smaller, but still can pack a nice punch... but only if you turn it up really loud. I really love the JBL Flip 6 because it is extremely portable, but I decided that I wanted to try this JBL Charge 5 because I love the camouflage pattern on it, and it seemed like a good in-between speaker from the other two speakers I'm comparing here. As it turns out, the JBL Charge 5 is the best choice for me in terms of portability, and sound. It's got a really nice full sound, and I don't have to turn it up quite as loud as the JBL Flip 6 to achieve the full sound I like. That means to me that I have more volume to play with if I really jam out to some good music. In the future I would like to try the JBL Extreme, even though I know it's not as portable as these other speakers I have. Anyway I really love this JBL Charge 5, and I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a bluetooth speaker that can get loud, but offers easy portability.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Audio Engineers point of view
author: Christo
content: I purchased two of these to work as a stereo pair in my apartment to obtain a nice full sound without having to really crank the volume to have an enjoyable experience and bother the neighbors.Well it all started out great, the white look clean and are small enough to not take up too much visual space. They also sound fantastic for a battery powered speaker, relatively full low end and crisp highs without needing to be EQed. They are setup roughly 15‚Äô feet from one another in opposing corners of my studio space. They add presence and a fullness that I was missing from my Notabrick Bluetooth speakers.Now for THE PROBLEMS:I synced the speakers together and switched them to ‚Äústereo‚Äù mode from the app with no problem using my iPhone 13 Pro running Bluetooth 5.1. When it was time to connect it to my stationary media hub it was intended for (a 2020 iPad 8th gen) it would only connect one speaker and not allow for a party link or stereo link between the two Charge 5‚Äôs anymore. It took my some time of testing and no help from the internet to find out that the Bluetooth 4.2 that the iPad uses means the JBLs could no longer connect in a pair. I figured they had their own connection protocol (perhaps wifi 2.4ghz) for party mode. This shared audio functionality will ONLY work if your device that is sending audio is Bluetooth 5.1.SECOND ISSUE:So I put the iPad aside and would only be using my iPhone for music since that‚Äôs the only way I could get the Stereo mode to function. But after 15-30 minutes of music playback the speakers will disconnect themselves from one another requiring you to manually go to them and reconnect themselves. Every third time or so they will also drop the Bluetooth connection requiring you to ‚Äúforget device‚Äù on your phone and resync Bluetooth to your host Charge 5 and then relink the speakers.This is all to say that if you want to use more than one speaker, even using a compatible Bluetooth 5.1 device that they are extremely finicky. Using a single Charge 5 has proved to be very reliable, sound great and look great. I am an audiophile and have many thousands of dollars in pro audio.The current tested Firmware version is 0.8.6.0 and has not been updated for over a year so this is unlikely to be fixed.UPDATE: I purchased two Charge 4 speakers to run through all the same testing and scenarios as the newer Charge 5 Models and found that with the exception of the occasional dropout and auto reconnection (perhaps once every two hours or so) these have solved all my issues. In fact, having the Aux plug on this model has also meant I can plugin my DJ decks to them when we are at the park and the primary speaker that is being plugged into will duplicate the signal and send it to the second speaker wirelessly with no issues. There is about one second of lag with this setup so the use of my DJ headphones is a requirement, but I love the added functionality. I also find the battery meters to be much more easy to read on the Charge 4. Finally, I do not know if it's because the transmission power of the Bluetooth 4.2 in the Charge 4 over the Bluetooth 5.1 in the Charge 5, but I find that I get a longer transmission range with no dropouts with the older Charge 4 model. On paper this should be backwards but testing 4 independent units in different scenarios have shown this to be recurring findings for me. I have used the 2020 iPad, iPhone 13 pro and Macbook M1 pro and a HD Firestick as my test subjects.I do notice that the Charge 5 has a slight edge in real world testing for maximum volume and clearly has a crisper high end to it where the Charge 4 sounds a little more round but is still very pleasing to the ear. I suggest to save a ton of money and pickup the Charge 4 if you are planning on using them in a multi speaker setup like me.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great little speakers
author: The pc builder
content: So let start off by I‚Äôm old school when it comes to selecting speaker. I have a massive surround system that sound great! I stumbled across the little speaker by accident. So I was doing a cell phone upgrade and they asked if I wanted a Bluetooth speaker versus 2 wireless stands‚Ä¶ I opted for the Bluetooth speaker as I had 2 wireless stands that work great. So I hooked this little flip 6 up and was amazed by the sound of this little thing. So I was doing a bit of research and finding that I could hook other speakers. So I opted to pick up another flip 6 and put them into stereo mode. I was floored by the sound out of these little speakers and the stereo field was amazing too!!! So then I was wanting to see how the charge 5 would stack up and then combine them. The one charge 5 has an edge on the bass but the mids and highs of the flip 6 held there ground and sounded a bit better to me. Now I starting thinking of 2.1 sound and this is where everything just shined very bright. Have the best of both worlds highs mids and lows in 3 small speakers!!! Some of the music that I demonstrate in this set up was Rush - The Weapon.. this has some really nice percussion section with some stereo left to right separation. I also played Led Zeppelin‚Äôs- Stairway To Heaven for the same reasons or the stereo left to right separation and over rounded sound. Great news it passes with flying colors and I give these 5 stars all day long. I‚Äôd like to pick up the extreme 3 and give it a go in this set up as it has the AUX jack that would make it useful enough to hook up external AM/FM with USB and SD card. In closing don‚Äôt overlook these speaker I really enjoy my little speaker and I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll love too!!!!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars It‚Äôs a Bose
author: ChrysJade
content: It‚Äôs a great speaker for taking with you or using in the kitchen while you cook, or visit out on the patio, camping, etc. The battery charge gives a fair amount of long play but also can quick charge about two hours of play off of about fifteen minutes of charge! It does have great Bose sound, as you would expect. Tho I was after a much bigger sound this time. I really wanted the JBL Boombox, as I have heard them play! But I didn't want to indulge and spend the $400 plus dollars. I‚Äôve had Bose sound before and this was down to a reasonable price for a change. It‚Äôs a great lil speaker. But if you want bigger sound you‚Äôre gonna have to spend the money and go for a bigger version of Bose. This is plenty loud for a great number of people who are just wanting the premium sound :) All in all was a good buy and worth the money for its size and output. Easy to no set up, outta the box charge and play! Also, there is a number of inexpensive covers, cases, frames that make it a ‚Äúboombox‚Äù with handles for easy take along. It came with its own charge cord and a quality clip for the heavy duty loop that‚Äôs built in, so you can clip/hang the speaker wherever you like. Plenty of colors to choose from as well, for both the speaker and accessories. Match or mix it up!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 9, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Surprisingly loud, no EQ controls, few caveats
author: Jacob Teeler
content: Bought this for work (I run a forklift and JBLs just arent loud enough) and was pleasantly surprised by how loud it gets. Sound quality is fantastic at all volume levels, its durable and holds up pretty well to the elements. The battery does genuinely last a full 8-10 hour shift playing constantly. A few things to note however.There are no EQ controls for it. Sound is well balanced but theres no bass boost, treble, no nada built in.The app is unnecessary once you get it set up with your device, really only need it to check the battery. The speaker will tell you what its battery percentage is if you turn it off and on though.Max volume is entirely dependent on the device its paired to. If i pair it to my PC, max volume is pretty quiet. If i pair it to my buddy's phone it gets pretty loud, but nowhere near as loud as it is paired to my phone.Volume controls are independent from the device and speaker. You can turn your speaker volume to max but your device is the primary control. So if you have the speaker on low volume and your phone all the way to the max, it wont be as loud as both at max, and vice versa. Its very odd.It does not remember the bluetooth volume of the device its paired to, so if you turn it off and use it the next day, it has a habit of being at full blown volume by default. Just be mindful.Other than that, its excellent and no one will be disappointed by it.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 22, 2024

content: You may have trouble getting this to play sound from you desktop computer, as I did. The unit misleads you by saying you need to download the app 'Bose connect'. I tried to, but could not get it to download from the App store or from the Bose website. Other Bluetooth speakers connected automatically for me, so this was a hassle. I tried to chat with the Bose help bot, but it was of no help; the lady on the phone at Bose tech support was of no help and disconnected mid-sentence and didn't call me back. I tried to return the item on Amazon, then saw a troubleshooting video. Open your 'systems settings' on your computer and select 'sound'; click the Bose option for speaker 'output'. For some reason this Bose unit doesn't default as the output as other Bluetooth speakers did on my computer. Then you should be able to hear it.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars there‚Äôs a time and place for it!
author: Steven Jerome Staten II
content: I purchased this because water broke my old Bose Revolve+. I don‚Äôt consider myself an audiophile, but I do listen to music religiously ‚Äî 100k+ hours annually ‚Äî and I can appreciate a crisp sounding speaker with nuance. This speaker lacks the nuance. It‚Äôs not terribly loud in my opinion, even on full volume in my small apartment. However, it is durable, and I love that it‚Äôs waterproof. Upon further research, I discovered that Bose is actually NOT worth the value for the money ‚Äî many audiophiles recommend purchasing from another brand, as these speakers can be made for less than $50 and sold for $400+. Initially I purchased the Bose Soundlink MAX and another Flex (product listed here) as well, in hopes of amplifying the sound as well as achieving stereo sound in my apartment.After doing some research, I returned the Soundlink Max and one of the Flex speakers as well. I purchased some ELAC speakers instead for HOME use, and kept one of the Bose Flex speakers for shower use and traveling, as I spend a lot of time on the beach and this is dust and drop resistant. I purchased this on Prime Day for $99 before tax. I would NOT say it‚Äôs worth $150 full price. The battery is not great. I can leave it charging overnight and it dies with moderate use before the day is over. Mediocre in performance overall.It‚Äôs worth nothing that when I purchased the Soundlink Max from Amazon, the box itself clearly states that the speaker comes from Bose ‚ÄúRETURNS AND REPLACEMENTS.‚Äù I believe the speakers sold on sale are probably speakers that were defected or returned by other customers. Keep that in mind!

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Keeping 2 of these paired is continual work.
author: Cliffton Mcintire
content: These speakers are OK to take to the beach and setup for a special occasion.These SUCK for everyday use. Once you set up a pair of these, they will randomly forget about each other, and then repair individually with your playback source so they must be re-paired to each other. Even without any interraction with other bluetooth play sources, they will randomly forget about each other.Here's what I have to do Every. Effing. Day.- Figure out which player(s) want to pair with them and disconnect, at the source.- Some play sources will reconnect automatically as I restart the speakers for pairing. These sources must fully purge the bluetooth speaker configuration so you can successfully re-pair the speakers.If I'm lucky, re-pairing goes "smoothly", but requires a very specific ritual:- Turn off secondary speaker (you'll figure out which one this is after a few hours of pointless BS)- Turn off primary speaker.- Turn on primary speaker.- At this point your secondary _might_ turn on, and you're good to go.- About half the time you must turn on the secondary yourself.- If you had to turn on the secondary, then you need to press the bluetooth pairing button- At this point the speaker _might_ re-pair- If they don't re-pair then you must also sacrifice a goat and then do the FULL RE-PAIR procedure:FULL RE-PAIR:- Turn off both speakers- Turn on your primary- Open your proprietary Sony app on your phone, find primary- Set up pairing mode- Turn on secondary- Find secondary and add to pair- Let them negotiate for 30 seconds, or 5 minutes.- You might need to bring both speakers and phone within 10 feet of each other for this to workOnce everything's re-paired, you can reenable the speakers on your playback source.Be very careful not to pair to one of them after they've forgotten each other, because then it's likely that you'll have to set everything up again. Be aware that many systems will automatically reconnect to whichever was primary, whether the primary is aware of the secondary at that moment or not. So they are continually breaking themselves.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Sony srs-xp700 vs JBL partybox 310
author: rw
content: Let's be honest, you're probably looking at the Sony xp700 because the JBL partybox 310 is sold out and because it's now $100 less than the JBL. Well, the JBL is indeed a better "party' speaker. Much better/deeper bass at volume, better light features, easier to transport with the wheels and telescoping handle, and it even has a hole for a speaker stand, meaning you can elevate it over a dance floor and project the sound further. If your primary use case is throwing medium to large dance parties or hosting events, hands down go with the JBL. Keep in mind, neither speakers have RCA or XLR inputs, so if you're trying to start a side-hustle as a DJ, neither speaker will be the best choice, but the JBL is the closest to an amateur DJ speaker.However, the Sony is actually a better "casual" speaker. IMO, it looks less ostentatious and more classy/understated than the JBL, with a more subtle light feature. It looks good and will aesthetically work just about anywhere, from a formal social event to a casual house party with friends. It has better sound quality at low volumes and simply a greater range of lower volume levels. Meaning, if you want softer background music during a dinner or a social event, the Sony will give you a wider range of volume levels to work with, whereas the JBL wants to blast music as loud as possible. Further, I feel the Sony has a more balanced sound and is just more usable for a wider range of situations, barring loud raves or crazy dance parties. The Sony also offers better battery life, and has battery saving features, which means the battery might last longer than the JBL over the years, since it will need fewer charge cycles.In conclusion, if you're a wanna be DJ, just looking to host dance parties and basement raves, stick the JBL. However, if you're like most people, and you want a good speaker for a wide range of situations, from listening to music in your living room, to throwing a birthday party, to hosting a formal cocktail event on your patio, the Sony is the more versatile option, aside from not having ANY audio out jack to daisy chain with different brand speakers and not being able to mount it on a speaker stand. Overall, a decent buy as long as it's less than the JBL. AND COME ON SONY, GIVE US SOME VERSATILITY AND LET US USE SPEAKER STANDS AND AUDIO OUTPUTS!!!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Stupid little problem
author: Kindle Customer
content: Love everything about the speaker... but theres one stupid little problem. There are these small rubber feet that go on the side of the speaker so that it can stand vertical or horizontal while listening. The rubber feet on the bottom of the vertical side are built really well, but the feet on the horizontal side are horrible and fall off really easily. I've had it for a month and a half, brought it 3 or 4 places, and I have one rubber foot left for the horizontal side. The rest fell off easily in transport and they sell them for $9 each online. Worst part is that the speaker isn't really that tall, so I've preferred having it horizontal on a table or countertop but now it doesn't sit balanced on its side which causes it to rattle against the counter/table. Classic stupid little problem that some people won't care about, but unfortunately it drives me crazy and it's probably too late to return it to upgrade to the better model.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars This is one BIG (and BASS HEAVY) speaker!
author: S. Rozell
content: When I looked at the box on my doorstep, I thought that Amazon had done another one of those too-big-of-a-box-jobs for a much smaller product. WOW! Was I wrong!! This thing is huge!!!Anyway, exclamation marks aside, I did not read the dimensions for this beast but it's over 2 feet tall (26"!) and at least a foot square for the footprint. Needless to say, the guy who recommended the wagon to carry this portable speaker is spot-on. There is no way you're throwing this on your shoulder and walking down the street.For the sound, it is definitely a BOOMbox. I've tried the Hyperboom and the JBL Boombox and they don't compare with both the depth and overall sound output of this thing. Then again, those other two in size are more along the lines of the XG500, not nearly the size of this one. Anyway, it has thunderous bass and really good mids and highs. Can't say I'm a huge distinguisher in terms of the latter two sounds, but the overall sound is just good quality.Overall, I paid $338 for an Amazon Warehouse Deal and it's the most I'd ever pay for one speaker (called "Acceptable" but I do not see anything that makes this less than "Very Good" or even "Like New"?). For that price point, it's definitely worth it. At the retail price, I'm pretty sure I would NOT have considered it as any speaker over $400 is going to have a hard time justifying itself.One other important note for those that like to have multiple speakers (and have suffered issues with JBL's systems): It easily hooks into my Bluetooth, as well as Party-Connects with my various other Sony speakers (XB33, XB43, and XG500).

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Very robust and appealing sound
author: C. Myers
content: I got this for my wife for Christmas. She's a music teacher and vocal director at a small school. Every year she hosts a musical and other musical-related things. In the past she was using a very small pill style speaker for rehearsals. That old speaker would not come close to filling the auditorium during rehearsals, and the house speakers are often inaccessible during rehearsal hours for various reasons.I got her this since it will accept a microphone and guitar/keyboard input, Bluetooth audio and has a very good battery life spec. Sonically, this is a lot closer to the auditorium speakers so her students will come a little closer to "practicing like they play".This speaker has a whole lot of features with modest sound customization. Based on my wife's reaction, this speaker will do essentially everything she would ask it to. This includes PA system, speaker for rehearsals and performances, and home listening and entertaining. Also, the battery life on this thing is very good in real world use as well.It seems like it is well-built and is relatively hefty at around 38 lbs. For this reason, I also got my wife a dolly-style collapsible luggage carrier to make transport easier.The sound on the SRS-XP700 is very good overall. The balance is pretty solid. The sound stage is pretty consistent and full in a standard room, and also fills a large space or outdoors very well. She seems satisfied with the dynamics of it as well.Overall, it was a great purchase for her, and I would buy it again.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Not loud, bad quality sound.
author: Grumpy Dad
content: For $48 you can get the SRS XB13, turn it up all the way and you will drown out the sound of this speaker at 50% volume, maybe even 60%. That's pathetic, and I tested it.At 25%, people in the room with me were carrying on a quiet conversation 4' away from the speaker.^^^ That's ALL you need to know right there^^^ But I will carry on.At 100%, if I walk away 40', I can easily carry on a quiet conversation and not hear the lyrics of the speaker.The lights seem to have no rhythm or rhyme to them. They just randomly blind. They remind me of those old robotic characters at chuck e cheese that just kinda danced around randomly.The lights are very muted as well, and then I realize the lights are NOT on the speaker itself, they are reflecting off of the grab bars onto the surface of the speaker.I used to love sony products. I strived to get everything Sony. Not I can name one that I have. I dont know what happened to them. They were the quality that no one could beat seemingly forever but yea they cost alot.Maybe this is just how bluetooth speakers work. We tried on an android device and apple device. The volume was the same.The sounds overall I should note, are very muted. No crystal clear highs, the mid range seemed like they turned it way down to be almost like a heavy metal tuned speaker.Dont get me wrong it was ok. I wouldnt be upset if this was only $100 and I wasnt trying to get something loud enough to fill an outdoor picnic pavilion. I need people in the back to hear what is being said over the mic, and shouldnt need to turn to 100% to make that happen, but I also want those people enjoying the music loud enough outside of the pavilion and then as you get inside get loud enough whereas people might even dance. This just doesnt put out that volume. Maybe my expectations are too high, but the JBL party box 110 I listened to one day, was damn loud, and it wasnt on the highest volume.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Disappointing
author: Carolina Cuevas
content: I will not say the speaker is bad per say because it does sound good but in an enclosed room. If you are outside even in a small space it is not loud enough. For it being a Sony I would have honestly thought the sound outside would have been better. Being honest I purchased a speaker from a local flea market that sounds louder and it was 1/3 the price. I am a bit disappointed because we LOVE music in our home, we have speakers almost in every room so we are not having to lug them around. I purchased this one mainly to take to the beach and to utilize outside when having get togethers. I will add though that when it is plugged in, and it may just be in my head, but it seems to be louder than when it's just running on the battery which defeats the purpose of a portable speaker with extreme sound. Also the cover does not seal at 100% and although it didn't get inside the compartment where you plug in the extension cord, it did seem as it was wet in the inner part of the seal. And this was just with normal splash of water from when we got out of the pool at home and out of the water at the beach. As stated in the beginning, it works but this speaker is honestly best used for maximum sound quality in an enclosed room vs outdoor.

title: 1.0 out of 5 stars Sound, bass, and party mode are pretty terrible
author: SSSJ
content: I don't usually write reviews, but I feel duped by all of the positive reviews on this speaker and wanted to say something! I bought 2 of these speakers because I often host outdoor dance events and was excited that it could run on batteries and be linked to another speaker. But I was very disappointed when I got the speaker and started to use it. Here are the issues I had:1. The sound is very quiet when the speaker isn't plugged in! A tiny little bluetooth speaker could contend with this huge speaker for volume when it's running on batteries.2. The bass is just TOO MUCH. If you're only going to use this speaker to play loud house music or something, then maybe that's ok. But playing normal music on this speaker (even with the bass turned down) is uncomfortable and the bass drowns out other instruments in the song.3. Party mode (connecting 2 speakers) just doesn't work! It's constantly skipping like a busted CD. There's NO WAY I could ever use 2 of these speakers for a public dance.4. I can't even use this speaker to connect to my computer to watch a movie over bluetooth. I had the same issues with skipping sound.All in all, this speaker is pretty useless to me and I'm sad that I can't return it at this point, after finally discovering all of the above issues. I hope other folks don't make the same mistake.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 21, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Decent sound quality- LACKS BASS
author: Scott M
content: The wonderboom 4 is overall is decent speaker especially for rugged terrain and portability. It outshines many competitors for how durable it is with its long battery life and 360 sound. For the price, it definitely lacks ‚Äúdeep bass‚Äù as advertised. I‚Äôll go over the 3 important things; sound quality, battery life, durability.1. Sound quality (for its size)- 6/10-the sound on its small shell is impressive. instruments and vocals sound good alone 3/4 volume. lacks in bass across the board. to advertise this as ‚Äúdeep bass‚Äù is completely false. The bass sounds like loud iphone quality bass. Once at full volume the vocals and instruments collide and the bass is gone too lol.2. Battery life- 10/10-the battery will last you a long time without recharging. I would not be worried about taking this thing all day on one charge.3. Durability- 10/10-the material is rough and feels amazing in hand. I would definitely say this is the most durable speaker I have owned just from feeling the material making it up.Overall- It‚Äôs a nice portable speaker but if it is worth it for you depends on what you use it for. If you are inside and want a shelf or shower speaker, i would not recommend this speaker. If you will bring this thing everywhere with you and want a sleek look and good vocals/music without the need of deep bass, I would highly recommend if it‚Äôs on sale! $100 is pushing it and if you add $30, a JBL flip 6 would be better sound and bass with the same durability and long battery life. Or go with the wonderboom 3 if you don‚Äôt mind the old charging cable, because they both sound identical.OVERALL RATING 7/10

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Doesn't remember stereo pair and turns off after 15 minutes even while plugged in
author: Watermelon Love
content: I am new to Ultimate Ears but not to Logitech. Logitech speakers failed me all three times. I vowed never to buy a Logitech speaker again, but reviews were positive for the Wonderboom lineup. This speaker is incredibly loud, but the sound is on the shrill side‚Äîtoo much treble and too little bass.I'd still keep the two Wonderboom 4s I bought, but Ultimate Ears makes these speakers turn off automatically even while plugged in after 15 minutes of inactivity. This means that, if you're relying on these speakers for phone, tablet or computer notifications, you're out of luck. What a bone-headed move, Ultimate Ears. How many returns have you gotten over this?Additionally, these speakers do not remember stereo pairing, and I have found stereo pairing to be a nightmare. It takes on average four attempts to get this to work because Bluetooth connection to the device gets lost along the way.I've used lower-priced Bluetooth speakers from Sony, Creative and Tribit that didn't turn off like you do or forget stereo pairing, Wonderboom.What is up with your design team, Ultimate Ears? Didn't anyone test how unfriendly these speakers are to use? They're terrible!I wondered‚Äîand boom!üí•‚Äîback to Amazon these speakers went!

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Annoying brief disconnects on Samsung Galaxy S24 Ultra
author: AB
content: This is an otherwise fine speaker but for no reason it will briefly stop playing music and then resume playing for no rhyme or reason - no notifications or text messages received. This is behavior right out of the box.Other people online are saying this has something to do with the device and compatibility towards newer Samsung Galaxy phones. It does this on my Samsung Galaxy S24 Ultra.Should not be happening on a brand new device and nobody outside of Samsung community webforum members seem to acknowledge it as this issue appears to go back to Wonderboom 3. Replacing the unit will not fix a compatibility issue, and while this should be resolved through a firmware update, the fact that this is still presenting through their last generation of the product tells me this isn't going to get resolved.My Wonderboom 2 and Megaboom 3 do not have this issue on the same device.To Ultimate Ears: Please fix this so I can confidently buy your products again. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Big sound in a small package, but quite pricey
author: bobwatts
content: I have always ascribed to the philosophy that if I‚Äôm going to listen to something, I require it to reproduce the One True Sound. In other words, as close to the original sound as possible. And I listen to music literally all day, sometimes all night also. I don't consider myself an "audiophile", a term that is overused, but I am extremely discerning and won't tolerate a poor speaker for more than a couple of seconds.Bluetooth speakers by definition are a compromise and will never be a substitute for a Real Sound System, but some manufacturers perform a lot better than others. And it is an undeniable fact that Bluetooth and wireless speakers are getting far better.In the last four years alone, I have handled, listened to, tested and experienced hundreds of Bluetooth speakers and have written quite a few reviews. (so have millions of other people, hang on I'll get to the point) I bought a lot of them. Paid money. Some over $500.I will rarely mention competitors' products but might "hint" at something.Other reviewers have made excellent observations and comments, and I will simply add my own, while trying to cover things that haven't been mentioned.For some reason, I have never purchased UE products, but I'm aware of them and they usually get great reviews. In retrospect, I probably have ignored them based on the price.This is a "real good" speaker, but I have to say that for the price, I have certainly heard better speakers for less or comparable prices.The biggest problem is a lack of bass response that other speakers can provide for the same or less money. I realize that with 1.5748" (40mm) drivers it's impossible to provide low frequency sound, but I will simply choose another speaker to get it. Having typed that, the bass that this speaker does provide is impressive for its size. At least comparable to similar "name brand" speakers in this class.The clarity of high frequency sounds and vocals is outstanding, and the mids are very good.As far as the "360¬∞ sound" claim is concerned, you can definitely hear a difference when one of the two side drivers is pointed at you.The default EQ sounds best (to me) by a HUGE margin. I can't imagine anyone liking the "outdoor" mode, it just removes any of the small amount of bass that is present. Although it makes the speaker noticeably louder, the sound is intolerable. I'll probably never press that button again. Putting it on the bottom out of sight out of mind was a good idea.The USB-C charging port is really buried in the housing, not sure why they did that.I realize the lanyard loop is stretchy, but I can barely get a finger in the thing without pulling it out a bit. Be nice if it was just a bit larger.I'm glad to see that money was spent on sound quality and no silly lights which I usually turn off.Controls are easy to use and function well.Pairing and other sounds are reasonable, and not the obnoxiously loud noises that other speakers make for some ridiculous reason.I did not test battery life or water resistance. I never get my speakers wet, and I have ways around battery life.I can't comment on longevity at this point of course, but that price may reflect quality that will last for many years, or at least I would like to think so.Personally, I would pass on this speaker (and that probably explains why I have for years) because I have heard and own speakers that sound FAR BETTER for the same or less in price. If you NEED a very small speaker, then this is an item to consider.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 10, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great sound
author: Andrew
content: This tiny speaker sounds phenomenal. Really clear highs and mids and the bass is really balanced and doesn't sound like a boombox. It has some heft (presumably from speaker magnets and battery) but is not too heavy or bulky to take with you. Whether it's worth a hundred bucks is the big question. I think there are better speakers out there for less. But the overall package is a nice one, so it might be worth it.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 10, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Great little Speaker, Awesome Sound, Durable, Easy to Sse and Waterproof!
author: Joey Joe
content: This is a great little bluetooth speaker! Ultimate Ears is pretty well known for quality bluetooth speakers that are easy to use. I've used several Ultimate Ears speakers before, and I'm most familiar with their "blast" speaker (which I've been using for years). The Wonderboom is the 4 rendition of their Wonderboom line up. Although the Wonderboom is not currently supported by the Ultimate Ears App (at the time of writing this review). I can say it is so easy to use that I don't really need the App to get this speaker to do what I want. It is easy to pair with bluetooth on your smart device, and although it doesn't have Alex built-in, you can use voice commands through your smart phone or device to help navigate through songs and volume needs. There are 3 buttons on the top, the little dot is to initiate bluetooth pairing, the big one in the center is for syncing this with another speaker, and the button with the line is for On or Off. The plus and minus buttons on the front are for manual volume control, and the tree shaped button on the bottom is for changing modes (Regular, Outdoor, and Podcast are the 3 preset equalizer modes). I was not able to determine if other modes could be added or adjusted. I can say, the regular mode sounds pretty awesome for music especially considering how small this speaker is; less than 4 in wide and less than 4.5 in tall. Even outdoors I find the regular mode sounds great, the outdoor mode just seems to me to boost mid and treble notes to allow the sound to travel further. I like the 360 degree sound. I like that this speaker is waterproof and floats, but I haven't tested those feature. What I like most about it being waterproof is I don't have to worry about accidentally leaving it in the rain, but it makes this speaker valid for boating and water sports, and perfect for use around pools and outdoor water activities. I like that this charges with a USB C cable, which they do include (you provide the USB power source). The charging port is easy to open and close. The short loop/strap on top has a little stretch to it, and is great for carrying this around, hanging on a nail or hook, or to tether it to just about anything else for that matter. I think may favorite part, aside from how easy this is to use, is the battery life. From my experience, it definitely gets the 14 hours of play specified. I used this for an entire weekend with just the original charge! They also claim this is drop-proof from 5 feet, and they offer a 2 year warranty! Its a great little speaker, awesome sound, durable, easy to use and waterproof!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 7, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic sound, better than the more expensive Boom4. Has jarring dropouts with Android
author: G. Adkins
content: I love testing bluetooth speakers, and couldn't pass this up when I saw it. This is a great little speaker, and sounds fantastic. The fact that it is waterproof is a great addition.In the hierarchy of my favorite bluetooth speakers, it's up toward the top. To give you some context, here's where it sits in my current speaker list:1) B&O Beosound 2 3rd Gen (Astonishing sound. Always my #1)2) B&O Beosound A1 Gen 2 (Very nice, but not for larger areas)3) HK Onyx 4 (Much larger - not waterproof - but outclasses every other normal speaker)4) Bose Soundlink Max (I'm not usually a fan of the Bose signature sound, but this is an excellent speaker)5) JBL Charge 4 - Very good budget speaker**6) The UE Wonderboom 4 (this speaker)7) Tribit StormBox 2 (about half the cost)As you can tell, this little guy punches WAAY above his weight and cost. Every time I turn it on, I love the sound. Every one of those above cost more that the UEWB4.However - there is one issue that makes it miss 5 stars - (I debated dropping it to 3 vs 4 stars). It drops out for a fraction of a second when streaming music. This happens about every 5 minutes or so, and is quite jarring.This happens on my Android (S24U) and my wife's Android (S23U), and is the ONLY bluetooth speaker that does this.My testing compared it on several tracks, switching back and forth between the this speaker and another. The most comparable speaker I found was the Tribit StormBox2, and it beats it in most categories.If you get one that doesn't drop out (or you don't use Android) recommended. Otherwise keep on searching.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 27, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great little speaker, but missing features from old Booms
author: Lee T. Sang
content: I currently use a UE Boom 2 to listen to podcasts while showering and was intrigued by this Wonderboom 4 since it has the advertised Podcast Mode. The use of USB-C to charge is also a big plus.The default mode is bass heavy which is great for music. It's pretty surprising coming out of this tiny speaker. However, I like to turn it up in the shower when listening to podcasts so I can hear it clearly. That's where I thought the Podcast Mode would come in great. Unfortunately it removes pretty much all the bass. Voices are clear and it can get loud, but it just sounds really tinny, like a laptop speaker. I actually found the Outdoor Mode to be my preferred way to listen to podcasts. It reduces the bass without removing it completely.The use of an actual physical button on top is also a welcome change coming from the Boom 2 that required taps that never worked on 100% of the time.One thing I do miss compared to the Boom 2 is an app. I wish the Wonderboom 4 could be integrated into the app so I could do things like silence the startup sound, have it stay on the last used sound mode on startup, and turn it off from the app when I'm not near the speaker.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 21, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Punches well above it's weight
author: E.Swope
content: Despite having a ridiculous number of speakers in this house I had to try Ultimate ears. Both the wonderboom and Boom have made so many top 10 lists I had to find out what I was missing. That said, I was skeptical, in part because my favorite Sony speakers never wound up on the list (and yes, they are better than several which did). So, I was skeptical of the lists and did not know Ultimate Ears. It was my loss because it is, they both are, great little speakers. I may well put together a top 10 of my own one day, and if and when I do, Ultimate Ears will surely be on it. At this point I want to say that some speakers work better for some people and some for others. It is a matter of your personal taste in music, balance, tonality. All that said I can not think of many people who would not be impressed with this speaker. I wish I had audio specs and feel somewhat at a loss writing a review without them. I would be surprised if it did not have full range sound. Not only is the volume, clarity, balance exceptional, it has a surprising level of detail, comparable to Sony (which does have full range) and maybe even B & O or Klipsch (which have different tonal qualities). I was surprised that it transmitted things like breath on a microphone, and there were moments of bell-like clarity which I have heard almost exclusively with Sony's XM1000 headphones.It also has surround sound, rich bass, no noise or artifacts at any level, and while I imagine it would be most beloved by rock listeners it plays well with jazz. I take speakers through a full range when I test them, and there is nothing which made me go running for another speaker, which quite a few have.It is easy to use, easy to carry and it sounds great. The build and finish is in many ways comparable to Sony's XB series but in my personal opinion it is most nearly comparable to JBL, though I think Ul6timate Ears, but the Boom4 and Wonderboom are more detailed and have a broader frequency range. I do not have a way to test that, so consider it opinion.It doers skip forward and back, and if I have a withhold at all it is that I really do not like the double and triple tapping, long hold, etc. I much prefer dedicated buttons, which this speaker does have for tws stereo pairing. The sound and level of detail is so good that I won't add my usual gripe about lack of high res blue tooth protocols. It really is a very surprising little speaker, and I can see why it made so many top ten lists. If you are still on the fence, try to find a way to listen to this before you buy. It's a very good little speaker.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 6, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Expensive for it's sound.
author: J. Victor
content: Ultimate Ears is sort of like JBL to me (I have many JBL speakers btw, I'm not a hater, 2 Partybox 100's, 1 Partybox 1000, JBL Xtreme 1, 2, and 4, many JBL Flips etc.) Some of their stuff is just overpriced for what you are getting. I would say the Partybox 100's were definitely worth their price, and the Parbybox 1000, but the Xtreme's and Flips are just too much money for the sound you get. This Wonderboom 4 is like that.It's not a bad sounding speaker. It's warm, plays voices and acoustics nicely, it's just missing meaningful bass. The Earfun U Boom is half the price and sounds bigger with deeper bass. It's also boosted a bit in the mid range, which just gets worse when you use "Outdoor" and "Podcast" modes. They are unusable to me.Outdoor mode BOOSTS THE MIDS to a ridiculous degree. That's not what is needed for outdoor, you have to boost bass to give it presence and not get lost outside with all of the other sounds.Podcast mode CUTS the already meager bass out entirely, and boosts the mids. It sounds like a toy. You want voices to sound natural and warm, why they did this I have no idea. You should listen to podcasts in normal mode, where they sound good.....I would recommend saving your money and getting a Earfun UBoom, it sounds better, it's warmer with deeper bass and half the price. Same volume at max. OR, you can buy 2x UBooms and pair them in stereo. The UBooms have the same great 360 degree sound of the Wonderboom 4. The wonderboom 4 sounds like a toy against the 2 UBooms.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 4, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great sound in a little size
author: LS.
content: The things I want the most in a portable speaker is great sound, small size and consistent connectivity and this speaker delivers all of those things. Also, for how small it is, the speaker has great sound range and a decent battery life. I also have the Ultimate Ears MEGABOOM speaker which is twice the size and they have the same quality but this version is half the size. I don't think this wonderboom is compatible for pairing with the megaboom or if it is then I couldn't get it to work. A big bonus for me is the little loop on the top of the speaker so that is can be hung up. Camping, tailgate, at a BBQ etc there are plenty of times where it's easier to have it hung up than trying to find a place to set it down. My favorite thing about this brand is the HUGE + and - buttons on the side of the speaker that function as the volume controls. There is no need to fiddle with tiny buttons, it's so easy to change the volume and anyone around can easily figure that out. I did not test out the waterproof capabilities but it is nice to know it is designed to be durable for all sorts of activities.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great speaker; excellent sound and everything-proof
author: AZ123
content: I'm lining up with the people who love the Ultimate Ears Wonderboom 4 speaker. I'd thought of getting a previous Wonderboom model, but despite all the acclaims from Wirecutter and elsewhere, I just didn't like the idea of using a mini-USB charging cord in this day and age. The Wonderboom 4 speaker upgraded to USB-C, so getting this was a no-brainer.This speaker lives up to the hype. Despite its compact size, it has a really big sound that's clear, has plenty of bass, and great clarity in the mids and highs. It works well both indoors and out, but I'm mostly inclined to use it indoors or while camping/hiking, given its small size and its virtual indestructibility. (I especially like that it floats.) I'm given to using larger speakers outside, like the Lodge (a really amazing product), but for combined portability and sound quality, the Wonderboom rules.The Wonderboom pairs quickly and well, and is very intuitive in its use. I've seen complaints from Samsung users about bluetooth dropouts, but as an iPhone person, this just has never happened in my experience with the Wonderboom. Overall, the speaker works well and sounds great, is portable, and can take a licking in the great outdoors. Just don't play it too loud and upset people in the next campsite, I guess. Great product.

content: I ordered this on a whim because I liked the look of it, and it's my new "small portable" style speaker I bring with me places.First off, this isn't the greatest speaker ever made, but at this price and for this size, it's pretty spectacular, and I love the features it comes with, especially the outdoor mode.My only "issue" with this speaker is the cover for the charging port can be hard to close sometimes, you have to push it in from the bottom angle first and then the top goes into place which can be annoying (plus sometimes it does seem like it gets a bit loose and I have to push it back in again) but it's a small complaint and the speaker still works great.Overall I give this speaker a 9/10, definitely recommend, great budget speaker at a good price and is very good sounding for its size.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome Small Speaker - Ultimate Ears Wonderboom 4
author: ROBOTO
content: The Ultimate Ears Wonderboom 4 is a top-notch small speaker. I don't have many speakers as small as this one (it's about the size of a softball), but I can confidently say it's the best small speaker I own. Most of my Bluetooth speakers are about the size of a tall soda can, and this Wonderboom beats them all hands down.The size doesn't compromise the sound quality at all. The Wonderboom delivers better treble, mids, and bass than some of my bigger Amazon vendor speakers. You can really tell it's high quality the moment you open the box and feel the materials and weight. Even the turn-on and turn-off chime sounds premium compared to my other speakers.While it doesn't exceed the sound quality of my Bose SoundLink (which costs more, of course), the Wonderboom 4 is perfect for tossing in my tennis bag. It's small, but it packs a great sound. It would be even better with another one to pair for stereo sound.The only downside is the price, but if you can snag it for $70 or less, it's a must-buy.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great Sound from a Small Package
author: Harold G. Meeks Jr.
content: The small size of this speaker made me skeptical that it could really put out bass, but I was wrong. I don‚Äôt know quite how the designers did it, but this speaker doesn‚Äôt just put out a decent amount of bass, but overall has a good, balanced sound that matches a larger bluetooth speaker that I have. It has a 360 degree dispersion pattern, which makes it useful in many different contexts. Pairing it was really easy - in fact, there is a transparent, removable sticker that prompts you on how to turn it on and pair it. The manual is similarly user-friendly - easy to read diagrams and text. This thoughtful design continues to the speaker itself, with it‚Äôs large plus and minus for adjusting volume, and it‚Äôs rubberized bottom to prevent sliding. Charging is via USB-C (great!) and a short charging cable is included. I am so impressed overall with this speaker - it is definitely a notch above other bluetooth speakers I have used.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars No Competition
author: Nicholas
content: JBL Flip 6 Bluetooth speaker. I‚Äôve been meaning to do a proper review of this speaker for a while now, but finding the time to do so has been difficult. As I mentioned before in a previous post, JBL‚Äôs Bluetooth speakers are excellent. As someone who prefers a HiFi setup (individual components like a receiver, CD player, turntable, bookshelf speakers, etc.), I have never been a fan of Bluetooth speakers. I prefer the definition, clarify, and instrument separation you find in a good pair of passive bookshelf speakers powered by a clean amplifier or receiver, and that preference has not changed. But being able to easily take your music with you wherever you go does have its benefits. I‚Äôve been through quite a few Bluetooth speakers over the years, mainly Ultimate Ears speakers, and I couldn‚Äôt believe how poor the quality of sound was from those speakers. I pretty much gave up on Bluetooth speakers until I decided to try out the JBL Flip 6. For such a small speaker, I could not believe how powerful and clean the sound was. I‚Äôve since tried out the JBL Charge 5, the JBL Xtreme 3, and even the JBL Boombox 3, and each one of those speakers produces great sound. The JBL Boombox 3 is monstrous, and no one really needs that kind of sound unless you‚Äôre entertaining guests in a small or medium-sized venue. At the end of the day, I will always prefer to unwind with a CD or vinyl record played through my stereo receiver and bookshelf speakers at home, and a Bluetooth speaker will never match the clarity and definition of a great pair of passive bookshelf or tower speakers fed by a high-quality amplifier or receiver, but JBL‚Äôs Bluetooth speakers are a good investment if you want to be able to take your music with you. Again, I recommend the Flip 6, but if you‚Äôre able to spend a little more money I recommend the Charge 5 or Xtreme 3.I photographed my Flip 6 perched on two books for scale and also for the promotion of literacy. You know I can‚Äôt help myself. By the way, both of those books in the photo are superb.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Small yet powerful little speakers that sound great!!!
author: The pc builder
content: So let start off by I‚Äôm old school when it comes to selecting speaker. I have a massive surround system that sound great! I stumbled across the little speaker by accident. So I was doing a cell phone upgrade and they asked if I wanted a Bluetooth speaker versus 2 wireless stands‚Ä¶ I opted for the Bluetooth speaker as I had 2 wireless stands that work great. So I hooked this little flip 6 up and was amazed by the sound of this little thing. So I was doing a bit of research and finding that I could hook other speakers. So I opted to pick up another flip 6 and put them into stereo mode. I was floored by the sound out of these little speakers and the stereo field was amazing too!!! So then I was wanting to see how the charge 5 would stack up and then combine them. The one charge 5 has an edge on the bass but the mids and highs of the flip 6 held there ground and sounded a bit better to me. Now I starting thinking of 2.1 sound and this is where everything just shined very bright. Have the best of both worlds highs mids and lows in 3 small speakers!!! Some of the music that I demonstrate in this set up was Rush - The Weapon.. this has some really nice percussion section with some stereo left to right separation. I also played Led Zeppelin‚Äôs- Stairway To Heaven for the same reasons or the stereo left to right separation and over rounded sound. Great news it passes with flying colors and I give these 5 stars all day long. I‚Äôd like to pick up the extreme 3 and give it a go in this set up as it has the AUX jack that would make it useful enough to hook up external AM/FM with USB and SD card. In closing don‚Äôt overlook these speaker I really enjoy my little speaker and I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll love too!!!! Update with about a week of playing some music and experimenting. The flip 6 turn on its end with tweeters up will produce the best sound and great sound stage. It does better in the vertical position cause the woofer and tweeter vertically aligned give better sound stage hence the vertical axis. Now pair it with a second and you‚Äôll have killer stereo mode. And the charge 5 to the center and you will love the sound as it acts like a sub reinforcement.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars It‚Äôs a Bose
author: ChrysJade
content: It‚Äôs a great speaker for taking with you or using in the kitchen while you cook, or visit out on the patio, camping, etc. The battery charge gives a fair amount of long play but also can quick charge about two hours of play off of about fifteen minutes of charge! It does have great Bose sound, as you would expect. Tho I was after a much bigger sound this time. I really wanted the JBL Boombox, as I have heard them play! But I didn't want to indulge and spend the $400 plus dollars. I‚Äôve had Bose sound before and this was down to a reasonable price for a change. It‚Äôs a great lil speaker. But if you want bigger sound you‚Äôre gonna have to spend the money and go for a bigger version of Bose. This is plenty loud for a great number of people who are just wanting the premium sound :) All in all was a good buy and worth the money for its size and output. Easy to no set up, outta the box charge and play! Also, there is a number of inexpensive covers, cases, frames that make it a ‚Äúboombox‚Äù with handles for easy take along. It came with its own charge cord and a quality clip for the heavy duty loop that‚Äôs built in, so you can clip/hang the speaker wherever you like. Plenty of colors to choose from as well, for both the speaker and accessories. Match or mix it up!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 9, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Surprisingly loud, no EQ controls, few caveats
author: Jacob Teeler
content: Bought this for work (I run a forklift and JBLs just arent loud enough) and was pleasantly surprised by how loud it gets. Sound quality is fantastic at all volume levels, its durable and holds up pretty well to the elements. The battery does genuinely last a full 8-10 hour shift playing constantly. A few things to note however.There are no EQ controls for it. Sound is well balanced but theres no bass boost, treble, no nada built in.The app is unnecessary once you get it set up with your device, really only need it to check the battery. The speaker will tell you what its battery percentage is if you turn it off and on though.Max volume is entirely dependent on the device its paired to. If i pair it to my PC, max volume is pretty quiet. If i pair it to my buddy's phone it gets pretty loud, but nowhere near as loud as it is paired to my phone.Volume controls are independent from the device and speaker. You can turn your speaker volume to max but your device is the primary control. So if you have the speaker on low volume and your phone all the way to the max, it wont be as loud as both at max, and vice versa. Its very odd.It does not remember the bluetooth volume of the device its paired to, so if you turn it off and use it the next day, it has a habit of being at full blown volume by default. Just be mindful.Other than that, its excellent and no one will be disappointed by it.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 22, 2024

I tried to chat with the Bose help bot, but it was of no help; the lady on the phone at Bose tech support was of no help and disconnected mid-sentence and didn't call me back. I tried to return the item on Amazon, then saw a troubleshooting video. Open your 'systems settings' on your computer and select 'sound'; click the Bose option for speaker 'output'. For some reason this Bose unit doesn't default as the output as other Bluetooth speakers did on my computer. Then you should be able to hear it.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars there‚Äôs a time and place for it!
author: Steven Jerome Staten II
content: I purchased this because water broke my old Bose Revolve+. I don‚Äôt consider myself an audiophile, but I do listen to music religiously ‚Äî 100k+ hours annually ‚Äî and I can appreciate a crisp sounding speaker with nuance. This speaker lacks the nuance. It‚Äôs not terribly loud in my opinion, even on full volume in my small apartment. However, it is durable, and I love that it‚Äôs waterproof. Upon further research, I discovered that Bose is actually NOT worth the value for the money ‚Äî many audiophiles recommend purchasing from another brand, as these speakers can be made for less than $50 and sold for $400+. Initially I purchased the Bose Soundlink MAX and another Flex (product listed here) as well, in hopes of amplifying the sound as well as achieving stereo sound in my apartment.After doing some research, I returned the Soundlink Max and one of the Flex speakers as well. I purchased some ELAC speakers instead for HOME use, and kept one of the Bose Flex speakers for shower use and traveling, as I spend a lot of time on the beach and this is dust and drop resistant. I purchased this on Prime Day for $99 before tax. I would NOT say it‚Äôs worth $150 full price. The battery is not great. I can leave it charging overnight and it dies with moderate use before the day is over. Mediocre in performance overall.It‚Äôs worth nothing that when I purchased the Soundlink Max from Amazon, the box itself clearly states that the speaker comes from Bose ‚ÄúRETURNS AND REPLACEMENTS.‚Äù I believe the speakers sold on sale are probably speakers that were defected or returned by other customers. Keep that in mind!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Don't believe every review you read, especially negative ones.
author: CP
content: Don't believe every review that you read...and only take isolated reported connectivity issues with a grain of salt, especially when they are incorrect. i.e. bluetooth 5.1 connectivity distance etc. Most connectivity issues in my 35 yrs of tech experience are due to "user error". Beyond that most can be, and are corrected with a firmware update. Now that being said, my opinion of course here on this unit follows. I have only had this 2nd generation Beosound A1 for a day, so keep that in mind. But right out of the box, this is the best sounding truly portable speakers that I have ever heard, period. Amazingly so, in fact that I have ordered a two more to fit an application that required exactly what these A1's offer. Beautiful clean sound that is loud enough in a large hockey puck style footprint the can be placed under a kitchen cabinets trim, virtually out of sight. How awesome it that? I had zero connectivity issues, and as a matter of fact I was surprised how well the connectivity worked with my iPhone, iPad, and 12" MacBook. Just as you would expect from a Bluetooth 5.1 device! I cannot and will not comment on Alexa connectivity because if I wanted Alexa capability I would just fire up one of the useless Alexa units that I have in my closet. I can only suspect B&O added Alexa capability because they have some licensing deal with Amazon. As for battery usage I have only had it for a day. But if it comes close to the 18 hours as listed this is even more a winner. And of course this is really portable so you can just plug it as you do your phone to fully charge in 2.75 hours. As for the microphones to be used as a conferencing type device....pretty cool. Though I have not tested them. It will be a bonus if they work as well as the rest of this device's features. You have to keep in mind that if you want Alexa, Siri, Google, and tele-conferencing capabilities you ALWAYS have to purchase dedicated devices for those needs.. If you can get a device like the B&O A1 (2ND GEN) that is "primarily" a portable battery operated speaker that you can bring to the beach to be just decent at those other things then you are way ahead of the game.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 10, 2021
